doc.after: On JuneÂ 27, 2002, the monsoon trough spawned a tropical disturbance southwest of Pohnpei.[3] The system rapidly organized that day, and at 2000Â UTC the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC)[nb 2] issued a tropical cyclone formation alert.[5] Early on JuneÂ 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA)[nb 3] classified the system as a tropical depression near the Mortlock Islands in the Federated States of Micronesia;[6] around the same time, the JTWC also initiated storm advisories.[3] Early on JuneÂ 29, the JTWC upgraded the system to Tropical Storm 08W,[3] and shortly thereafter the JMA named the system Tropical Storm Chataan.[6] After moving northwestward, the storm turned to the east, resuming a northwest track on JuneÂ 30 due to a subtropical ridge to the north. The track was erratic because the storm had not yet separated from the monsoon trough.[5][6] By JuneÂ 30, Chataan had steadily strengthened to severe tropical storm status, with 10-minute maximum sustained winds of 95Â km/h (60Â mph).[6]
